Parallels are quoted for this equation of the terms naîç and e ( prjßog from Plutarch,  who uses both words in describing the ritual of flogging at the altar of Orthia,  and from Attic Ephebe - inscriptions.  In spite of the obvious objection that we might have expected the contests to be called TO iiprjßiHov and not то naidixovy I have little doubt that Miss Chrimes has found the right explanation. 
Secondly,  ßoayoi are explained,  not as boys of the same age as the other members of their Agelai,  as is usually inferred from the statement of Hesychius,  but as youths of the status of Eirenes,  as Plutarch,  following Xenophon,  Resp,  informs us^.  The frequent mention of victories by a ßoayog ( or occasionally ß,  TtqaroTtafxnaldcJv ) does not seem
to support Miss Chrimes's view as definitely as she claims,  and I feel less confident that she is right on this point. 
Thirdly,  the mysterious Kasens are ingeniously accounted for as members of a less privileged class,  who could only be admitted to the Agelai if selected by some member of the »privileged class«,  which was admitted automatically.  Thus the word Kasen means not merely mate«,  but »foster - brother«.  On this view the Agelai comprised boys of three social classes,  ( a ) members of »privileged families«,  each of whom might select one ( or two ) boys as his Kasen ; ( b ) »the rank and file«,  who could neither select nor needed to be selected ; ( c ) a third class consisting only of Kasens,  ineligible for subsequent office except through admission to the Agelai.  It is suggested in chapter VI,  apparently as an afterthought,  that this class may correspond to the Mothakes of classical Sparta ( pp.  221 fF.  ),  whilst the Hypomeiones had apparently disappeared by Roman times.  The Synepheboi were also,  on this view,  elected from those already in the Agelai,  Kasens and non - Kasens alike,  by the Boagos ( though being ex l^pothesi an Eiren he was no longer an Ephebos ).  But before a Kasen could hold public office he had to be adopted and change his name to that of his adoptive father,  a process which would explain the fact that whilst the names of the boy - victors at the Sanctuary of Orthia,  who were of this status,  took the form A son of B,  Kasen to C,  when they were grown up and held office their names appear as A son of A,  Kasen to C.
